title: Psalms Chapter 46 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 46 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 46 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 46.

questions.question: According to Psalms 46:1, what is God described as?
questions.correctAnswer: Our refuge and strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:1 states, 'God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 46:2 says we will fear if the earth is removed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:2 says, 'Therefore will not we fear, though the earth be removed...,' indicating we will not fear.

questions.question: What natural event is mentioned in Psalms 46:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Waters roaring and mountains shaking
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:3 says, 'Though the waters thereof roar and be troubled, though the mountains shake with the swelling thereof.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 46:4, what makes glad the city of God?
questions.correctAnswer: A river and its streams
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:4 states, 'There is a river, the streams whereof shall make glad the city of God.'

questions.question: Where is God said to be in Psalms 46:5?
options: In the midst of her (the city)
questions.correctAnswer: In the midst of her (the city)
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:5 says, 'God is in the midst of her; she shall not be moved.'

questions.question: What happened when God uttered His voice, according to Psalms 46:6?
questions.correctAnswer: The earth melted
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:6 states, 'he uttered his voice, the earth melted.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 46:7 declares that the God of Jacob is our refuge.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:7 says, 'The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 46:8 invite us to do?
options: Come and behold the works of the LORD
Build a temple for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Come and behold the works of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:8 says, 'Come, behold the works of the LORD, what desolations he hath made in the earth.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 46:9, what does God do to wars?
options: Makes wars to cease to the end of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Makes wars to cease to the end of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:9 states, 'He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 46:10: 'Be still, and know that I am ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:10 says, 'Be still, and know that I am God.'

questions.question: What will God be exalted among, according to Psalms 46:10?
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:10 states, 'I will be exalted among the heathen.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 46:11 repeats that the LORD of hosts is with us.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:11 repeats, 'The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 46:9, what does God do to the bow and spear?
options: He breaketh the bow and cutteth the spear in sunder
He sharpens the bow and spear
He hides the bow and spear
He blesses the bow and spear
questions.correctAnswer: He breaketh the bow and cutteth the spear in sunder
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:9 says, 'he breaketh the bow, and cutteth the spear in sunder.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 46:5 say will not happen to the city of God?
questions.correctAnswer: She shall not be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:5 states, 'she shall not be moved: God shall help her.'

questions.question: What is the city of God called in Psalms 46:4?
options: The holy place of the tabernacles of the most High
questions.correctAnswer: The holy place of the tabernacles of the most High
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:4 refers to it as 'the city of God, the holy place of the tabernacles of the most High.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 46 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 46 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 46, what biblical truth would you share about God's presence during difficult times?
options: God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble
We should rely only on ourselves to overcome trials
Trials mean God has abandoned us
We must hide from troubles and avoid them
questions.correctAnswer: God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:1 clearly states God is a refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble, assuring believers of His constant presence. This is supported by verses 5 and 7 which emphasize God’s presence and help.

questions.question: How does Psalms 46 teach us to respond in faith when facing overwhelming circumstances like natural disasters or chaos?
options: Therefore will not we fear, though the earth be removed
We should fear and panic when the earth shakes
Ignore the situation and pretend it doesn’t exist
Run away from the problem without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Therefore will not we fear, though the earth be removed
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:2 encourages believers not to fear even when the earth is removed or mountains are moved, teaching trust in God’s protection despite turmoil. This is affirmed by verses 3 and 6-7 which describe chaos but affirm God’s power and presence.

questions.question: A believer feels shaken by conflict and asks how to maintain peace. According to Psalms 46, what spiritual discipline helps us recognize God’s sovereignty?
options: Be still, and know that I am God
Always be busy to avoid thinking
Argue with others to prove your point
Ignore God and rely on your strength
questions.correctAnswer: Be still, and know that I am God
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:10 teaches stillness and recognition of God's sovereignty as a way to experience peace amid conflict. This is supported by verses 7 and 11 which remind us God is with us as a refuge.

questions.question: How does Psalms 46 encourage believers to view God's role in stopping wars and violence?
options: He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth
War is the only way to solve problems
God is indifferent to human conflicts
questions.correctAnswer: He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth
questions.explanation: According to Psalms 46:9, God actively brings wars to an end and disables weapons, showing His desire for peace. This is consistent with verses 6 and 8, which portray God's control over kingdoms and desolations.

questions.question: When a believer worries about the stability of their life and surroundings, what truth from Psalms 46 can help them trust God?
options: God is in the midst of her; she shall not be moved
Everything depends solely on human effort
We must create our own security
Trust in wealth and possessions for safety
questions.correctAnswer: God is in the midst of her; she shall not be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:5 affirms that God's presence stabilizes the city of God, symbolizing believers’ lives, assuring they will not be moved. This is supported by verses 1, 7, and 11 emphasizing God's refuge and help.

questions.question: How does Psalms 46 teach us about humility and contentment in the face of worldly upheaval?
options: Be still, and know that I am God
questions.correctAnswer: Be still, and know that I am God
questions.explanation: Verse 10 teaches humility and contentment through stillness and acknowledgment of God's ultimate authority. This aligns with verses 1, 7, and 11 which remind us to trust God as refuge and strength.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to despair when seeing chaos around. Based on Psalms 46, what biblical truth should you share about God’s sovereignty?
options: The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge
Chaos means God has lost control
We must rely only on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 11 emphasize God’s presence with His people as their refuge, demonstrating His sovereignty even amid chaos. This reassures believers not to despair.

questions.question: How does Psalms 46 encourage believers to view God's help in times of early morning distress or urgency?
options: God shall help her, and that right early
God helps only after long delay
Help comes only from human leaders
questions.correctAnswer: God shall help her, and that right early
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:5 teaches that God’s help comes promptly, ‘that right early,’ encouraging believers to trust in God’s timely intervention. This is supported by verses 1 and 7, emphasizing God as a present help.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 46, what is the practical application for believers when facing spiritual or personal battles?
options: Trust in God who breaks the bow and cuts the spear
Fight battles using only human strength
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God who breaks the bow and cuts the spear
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes God breaking weapons of war, symbolizing His power to overcome spiritual and personal battles. Believers are encouraged to trust Him rather than rely on their own strength.

questions.question: How can the imagery of a river making glad the city of God in Psalms 46 help believers cultivate joy and peace in their spiritual lives?
options: Streams of God’s presence bring gladness and refreshment
Happiness is found only in worldly success
questions.correctAnswer: Streams of God’s presence bring gladness and refreshment
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:4 describes a river whose streams make glad the city of God, symbolizing divine provision refreshing the believer’s soul, promoting joy and peace. This is in harmony with verses 1 and 5.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 46, believers can be confident that even if kingdoms rage and the earth melts, God’s voice and power prevail.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:6 shows that though kingdoms rage and the earth melts, God's voice causes the earth to melt, demonstrating His supreme power over chaos.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 46 teaches that believers should fear natural disasters and lose hope when the earth is shaken.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 2 teaches believers not to fear even if the earth is removed or mountains fall into the sea, encouraging trust and faith rather than fear.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "God is our ______ and strength, a very present help in trouble."
questions.correctAnswer: refuge
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:1 states clearly that God is our refuge and strength, indicating He is a place of safety and power in times of trouble.

questions.question: How does Psalms 46 encourage believers to share the message of God’s power and refuge with others?
options: Come, behold the works of the LORD, what desolations he hath made in the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Come, behold the works of the LORD, what desolations he hath made in the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 8 invites believers to witness and share God’s mighty works and power over desolation, encouraging evangelism and testimony.

questions.question: What does Psalms 46 imply about the importance of trusting God rather than political or worldly powers during times of upheaval?
options: The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge
Trust in kings and kingdoms alone
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 11 affirm that God, not earthly powers, is the true refuge for His people, teaching believers to place trust in Him above all.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 46 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 46.

questions.question: In Psalms 46:1, God is described as a refuge and strength. How does this depiction relate to the concept of God as a 'rock' found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: Both emphasize God's stability and protection
Both highlight God's role as a creator
Both describe God's role in judgment
Both focus on God's role in prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize God's stability and protection
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:1 calls God 'our refuge and strength,' similar to how God is called a 'rock' in passages like Psalm 18:2, emphasizing His unshakable protection and stability.

questions.question: Psalms 46:2 speaks of not fearing though the earth be removed and the mountains carried into the sea. What literary device is primarily used in this verse?
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole
questions.explanation: The imagery of mountains moving into the sea is hyperbolic, emphasizing the total upheaval of creation and the psalmist's confidence in God despite chaos (Psalms 46:2).

questions.question: The phrase 'Selah' appears in Psalms 46:3 and Psalms 46:7. What is the most widely accepted significance of 'Selah' in these contexts?
questions.correctAnswer: A musical pause or reflection
questions.explanation: 'Selah', appearing in Psalms 46:3 and 46:7, likely signals a pause for contemplation or a musical interlude, inviting the reader to meditate on the preceding words.

questions.question: According to Psalms 46:4, what is the significance of the river whose streams make glad the city of God?
options: It symbolizes divine provision and joy
It represents the flood that destroyed the earth
It is a literal river in Jerusalem
It signifies the Red Sea crossing
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine provision and joy
questions.explanation: The river in Psalms 46:4 symbolizes the life-giving presence of God, bringing gladness to the city of God, which is the holy dwelling of the Most High.

questions.question: Psalms 46:5 states that 'God is in the midst of her; she shall not be moved.' How does this statement relate to the concept of Jerusalem as Zion in the Old Testament?
options: It affirms Jerusalem's spiritual security because of God's presence
It foretells the physical destruction of Jerusalem
It highlights the city's architectural strength
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms Jerusalem's spiritual security because of God's presence
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the theological theme that Jerusalem (often called Zion) is secure because God dwells there, a motif found in many Old Testament passages (Psalms 46:5).

questions.question: In Psalms 46:6, what is the significance of the earth melting after God utters His voice, from a Near Eastern cultural perspective?
options: It symbolizes God's overwhelming power over natural and political forces
It refers to volcanic activity near Jerusalem
It is a metaphor for drought
It describes a literal earthquake that destroyed enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's overwhelming power over natural and political forces
questions.explanation: The imagery of the earth melting at God's voice in Psalms 46:6 symbolizes divine supremacy over chaotic natural and political powers, a common theme in ancient Near Eastern literature.

questions.question: Psalms 46:7 and 46:11 both proclaim 'The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge.' What literary technique is used here?
questions.correctAnswer: Inclusio
questions.explanation: The repetition of this phrase at the beginning and end of the passage forms an inclusio, framing the Psalm and emphasizing God's protective presence (Psalms 46:7, 46:11).

questions.question: Psalms 46:8 invites the reader to 'behold the works of the LORD.' How does this call function as a rhetorical device in the overall structure of the Psalm?
options: It serves as a turning point leading to divine exaltation
It signals a change in speaker
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a turning point leading to divine exaltation
questions.explanation: The invitation in Psalms 46:8 marks a shift from chaos imagery to God's sovereign actions, preparing for the declaration of God's exaltation in verses 9-10.

questions.question: In Psalms 46:9, God 'breaketh the bow, and cutteth the spear in sunder.' What theological theme does this represent across Scripture?
options: God as the ultimate bringer of peace
God as a warrior demanding violence
God as a creator of weapons
questions.correctAnswer: God as the ultimate bringer of peace
questions.explanation: The breaking of weapons in Psalms 46:9 symbolizes God ending war and establishing peace, a recurring theme in prophetic literature (e.g., Isaiah 2:4).

questions.question: The phrase 'Be still, and know that I am God' in Psalms 46:10 is often interpreted as a call to what spiritual posture?
questions.correctAnswer: Trust and reverence
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:10 calls for stillness and recognition of God's sovereignty, encouraging trust and reverence amidst turmoil.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 46 repeatedly emphasizes God's presence as a source of refuge and strength in the face of natural disasters and enemy attacks.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Throughout Psalms 46, including verses 1, 5, 7, and 11, God's presence is affirmed as a refuge and strength amid chaos and threats.

questions.question: What is the significance of the term 'LORD of hosts' used in Psalms 46:7 and 46:11 in the ancient Israelite context?
options: It denotes God's command over heavenly armies and cosmic order
It refers to the king of Israel
It means God is a warrior against Israel
It is a title for the high priest
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes God's command over heavenly armies and cosmic order
questions.explanation: 'LORD of hosts' underscores God's authority over angelic armies and the cosmos, reflecting His supreme power in Israel's worldview (Psalms 46:7, 46:11).

questions.question: The phrase 'the city of God' in Psalms 46:4 is a typological reference to which biblical location that carries theological significance?
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 'The city of God' in Psalms 46:4 refers typologically to Jerusalem, the spiritual center and dwelling place of God in Israelite theology.

questions.question: Psalms 46:9 mentions that God 'maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth.' Which New Testament verse echoes a similar promise of peace?
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 5:9
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:9, 'Blessed are the peacemakers,' echoes the theme of God bringing peace found in Psalms 46:9.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 46:10 states, 'Be still, and know that I am ____. I will be exalted among the heathen.'
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states, 'Be still, and know that I am God,' emphasizing recognition of God's sovereignty (Psalms 46:10).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 46 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 46 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 46, what is God described as in times of trouble?
questions.correctAnswer: Refuge and strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:1 calls God 'our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble,' affirming His protective and empowering role. This aligns with other scriptures such as Psalm 18:2, Isaiah 41:10, Nahum 1:7, and Hebrews 13:6.

questions.question: What does the psalm say about fear when the earth is removed and mountains are carried into the sea?
questions.correctAnswer: We will not fear
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:2 states, 'Therefore will not we fear, though the earth be removed, and though the mountains be carried into the midst of the sea.' This expresses trust in God's sovereignty amid cosmic upheaval, echoed in Isaiah 54:10, Hebrews 12:26-27, Revelation 21:1, and Matthew 24:35.

questions.question: What natural imagery is used in Psalms 46 to express God's sustaining presence in the city of God?
options: A river whose streams make glad
A pillar of cloud and fire
questions.correctAnswer: A river whose streams make glad
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:4 mentions 'There is a river, the streams whereof shall make glad the city of God,' symbolizing God's life-giving and joyful presence. Similar imagery appears in Isaiah 58:11, Ezekiel 47:1-12, John 7:38, and Revelation 22:1-2.

questions.question: How is the city of God described in relation to God's presence?
options: She shall not be moved because God is in the midst
She will be destroyed by enemies
She will be hidden and forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: She shall not be moved because God is in the midst
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:5 states, 'God is in the midst of her; she shall not be moved.' This highlights God's protective presence ensuring stability, as affirmed in Zechariah 2:5, Hebrews 12:28, Matthew 16:18, and Revelation 21:3-4.

questions.question: What is the response of the nations when God utters His voice, according to Psalms 46?
questions.correctAnswer: The earth melted
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:6 says, 'he uttered his voice, the earth melted,' describing the overwhelming power of God's word over nations. This theme is echoed in Exodus 19:18, Joel 3:16, Nahum 1:5, and Revelation 6:14.

questions.question: Who is described as being with us as a refuge in Psalms 46?
options: The LORD of hosts, the God of Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts, the God of Jacob
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:7 and 46:11 both affirm, 'The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge,' emphasizing God's covenant faithfulness and almighty power. See also Isaiah 33:2, Jeremiah 16:19, Psalm 91:2, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: What invitation does Psalms 46 extend to the reader regarding the works of the LORD?
options: Come, behold the works of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Come, behold the works of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:8 invites, 'Come, behold the works of the LORD,' calling to witness God's mighty acts. This call to observe God's deeds aligns with Exodus 14:31, Isaiah 40:26, Luke 1:37, and Revelation 15:3.

questions.question: What does the LORD do to wars according to Psalms 46?
options: He makes wars to cease to the end of the earth
He uses wars to punish the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: He makes wars to cease to the end of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:9 declares, 'He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth,' portraying God's ultimate peace-bringing reign. This prophetic peace is echoed in Isaiah 2:4, Micah 4:3, Revelation 19:11, and John 14:27.

questions.question: Which weapons does God break and burn according to Psalms 46?
options: The bow, the spear, and the chariot
The sword, the shield, and the helmet
The axe, the spear, and the hammer
The sling, the staff, and the shield
questions.correctAnswer: The bow, the spear, and the chariot
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:9 says God 'breaketh the bow, and cutteth the spear in sunder; he burneth the chariot in the fire,' symbolizing the destruction of instruments of war. Similar imagery is found in Isaiah 2:4, Psalm 2:4, Joel 3:10, and Zechariah 9:10.

questions.question: What command and promise does God give in Psalms 46:10?
options: Be still, and know that I am God; I will be exalted in the earth
Run swiftly and proclaim His name
questions.correctAnswer: Be still, and know that I am God; I will be exalted in the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 46:10 commands, 'Be still, and know that I am God,' emphasizing trust and recognition of God's sovereignty. The promise of His exaltation aligns with Isaiah 45:22, John 5:44, Philippians 2:9-11, and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the repeated phrase 'The LORD of hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our refuge' in Psalms 46?
options: It affirms God's covenant faithfulness and mighty protection
It emphasizes human strength and wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God's covenant faithfulness and mighty protection
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase in Psalms 46:7 and 46:11 underscores God's unchanging presence and protection through His covenant with Jacob (Israel). This is consistent with Exodus 34:6-7, 2 Samuel 22:3, Romans 11:26, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: How does Psalms 46 portray God's control over creation in the face of chaos?
options: God controls the earth even when mountains shake and waters roar
God is overwhelmed by creation's chaos
God allows creation to destroy itself
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the earth even when mountains shake and waters roar
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 describe natural disasters like mountains shaking and waters roaring but affirm no fear because God remains sovereign. This is consistent with Job 38:1-11, Psalm 93:3-4, Nahum 1:3, and Mark 4:39.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'A Song upon Alamoth' in Psalms 46:1 suggest about the psalm's purpose or style?
options: It indicates a musical or liturgical setting for soprano voices
It is a historical event reference
It signals a prophetic oracle against enemies
It denotes a festival of harvest
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a musical or liturgical setting for soprano voices
questions.explanation: The term 'Alamoth' likely refers to a musical instruction for high voices, indicating the psalm was designed for worship. This aligns with similar musical notations in 1 Chronicles 15:20, Psalm 68:25, Exodus 15:20, and Colossians 3:16.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is reflected in Psalms 46:9 where God makes wars cease?
options: Ultimate peace through God's reign on earth
questions.correctAnswer: Ultimate peace through God's reign on earth
questions.explanation: The cessation of war to the ends of the earth anticipates the messianic kingdom of peace, as prophesied in Isaiah 9:6-7, Micah 4:3, Revelation 19:11-21, and Romans 14:17.

questions.question: How does Psalms 46 encourage believers in the midst of spiritual or physical turmoil?
options: Trust God as a refuge and be still to recognize His sovereignty
Rely on human strength and military might
Ignore the troubles and focus on wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God as a refuge and be still to recognize His sovereignty
questions.explanation: The psalm teaches reliance on God’s protection ('refuge and strength') and stillness to acknowledge His lordship (verse 10). This is supported by Psalm 62:5-8, Isaiah 26:3, Matthew 11:28-30, and Philippians 4:6-7.
